Detailed Description

This class implements Hidden Markov Model (HMM).

An HMM is defined as:

  • a discrete state space ,
  • an emission (observation) space (alphabet) ,
  • an initial state distribution ,
  • a transition distribution ,
  • an emission (observation) distribution .

The state variable has to be a discrete (integer) variable taking its values in [0,...,nstates-1].

The emission (observation) variable can be discrete or continuous. It can be also multidimensional. Moreover, the emission (observation) distribution can be decomposed. Examples for a 2D observation:

  • ,
  • ,
  • .

Using ProBT, such a decomposed emission distribution can be expressed using the plComputableObject class to define the emission distribution as a product.

Given an already constructed HMM, this class implements:

  • Evaluation: Given an observation sequence (or sequences), return the corresponding log-likelihood.
  • Decoding: Given an observation sequence, return the most probable state sequence.
  • Filtering: Given an observation as input, online update of the state distribution.
  • Simulation: Generate observation/state sequences according to HMM's parameters.

It also implements HMM's distributions learning (assuming that the number of states and the emission space are KNOWN):

  • Supervised Learning: Given a set of state/observation sequences, find the HMM's distributions that maximize the sequences likelihood.
  • Unsupervised Learning: Given a set of observation sequences, find the HMM's distributions that maximize the sequences likelihood.

plFloat plHMM::compute_states_probabilities_log ( const Observation_t &  observation,
std::vector< plFloat > &  states_probabilities_log 
) const

Compute the logarithm of the distribution over the states using a given observation and returns the corresponding log-likelihood.

Parameters
[in]observationthe observation vector.
[out]states_probabilities_logthe computed log-distribution.
Returns
the log-likelihood of the observation.

This method allows to use the HMM as a Bayesian filter to update, after each observation, the probability distribution over the states.

void plHMM::train_supervised ( const std::vector< ObservationSequence_t > &  observation_sequences,
const std::vector< StateSequence_t > &  state_sequences,
plLearnObject *  emission_distribution_learner,
plLearnObject *  init_state_distribution_learner = 0,
plLearnObject *  transition_distribution_learner = 0,
bool  tabulate_emission_distribution = false,
bool  tabulate_transition_distribution = true 
)

Supervised training.

Parameters
[in]observation_sequencesa vector of observation sequences.
[in]state_sequencesa vector of state sequences.
[in]emission_distribution_learneran online learning object to choose the form of the emission (observation) distribution to be learned.
[in]init_state_distribution_learneran online learning object to choose the form of the initial state distribution to be learned.
[in]transition_distribution_learneran online learning object to choose the form of the transition distribution to be learned.
[in]tabulate_emission_distributiona parameter to say if the emission (observation) distribution should be tabulated or not.
[in]tabulate_transition_distributiona parameter to say if the transition distribution should be tabulated or not.

Using this constructor, the observation dimension and type are extracted form the emission_distribution_learner object. If init_state_distribution_learner (transition_distribution_learner) is null, the initial state distribution (transition distribution) is learnt as a simple histogram (s).

The emission (observation) variable (O) can be discrete or continuous. It can be also multidimensional. Moreover, the emission (observation) distribution can be decomposed. Examples for a 2D observation:

  • ,
  • ,
  • .

Using ProBT, a such decomposed emission distribution can be expressed using the plLearnDistribVector class to define the learner of the emission distribution.

If you want to freeze a given distribution (instead to learn it), use special learner plLearnFrozenDistribution.

void plHMM::train_supervised ( unsigned int  nstates,
const std::vector< ObservationSequence_t > &  observation_sequences,
const std::vector< StateSequence_t > &  state_sequences,
int  obs_min_value,
int  obs_max_value,
bool  tabulate_emission_distribution = false,
bool  tabulate_transition_distribution = true 
)

Supervised training.

Parameters
[in]nstatesthe number of states.
[in]observation_sequencesa vector of observation sequences.
[in]state_sequencesa vector of state sequences.
[in]obs_min_valuethe min value for the observation.
[in]obs_max_valuethe max value for the observation.
[in]tabulate_emission_distributiona parameter to say if the emission (observation) distribution should be tabulated or not.
[in]tabulate_transition_distributiona parameter to say if the transition distribution should be tabulated or not.

Using this method, the observation is supposed to be one-dimensional discrete in the range [obs_min_value,...,obs_max_value]. All distributions are learnt as simple histograms.

plFloat plHMM::train_unsupervised_viterbi ( const std::vector< ObservationSequence_t > &  observation_sequences,
plLearnObject *  emission_distribution_learner,
plLearnObject *  init_state_distribution_learner = 0,
plLearnObject *  transition_distribution_learner = 0,
bool  tabulate_emission_distribution = false,
bool  tabulate_transition_distribution = true,
bool  left_to_right_init = false 
)

Unsupervised training using iterative viterbi algorithm.

Parameters
[in]observation_sequencesa vector of observation sequences.
[in]emission_distribution_learneran online learning object to choose the form of the emission (observation) distribution to be learned.
[in]init_state_distribution_learneran online learning object to choose the form of the initial state distribution to be learned.
[in]transition_distribution_learneran online learning object to choose the form of the transition distribution to be learned.
[in]tabulate_emission_distributiona parameter to say if the emission (observation) distribution should be tabulated or not.
[in]tabulate_transition_distributiona parameter to say if the transition distribution should be tabulated or not.
[in]left_to_right_initif true, state initialization will be "left to right" instead of random
Returns
the loglikelihood

Using this method, the observation dimension and type are extracted form the emission_distribution_learner object. If init_state_distribution_learner (transition_distribution_learner) is null, the initial state distribution (transition distribution) is learned as a simple histogram (s).

The emission (observation) variable can be discrete or continuous. It can be also multidimensional. Moreover, the emission (observation) distribution can be decomposed. Examples for a 2D observation:

  • ,
  • ,
  • .

Using ProBT, a such decomposed emission distribution can be expressed using the plLearnDistribVector class to define the learner of the emission distribution.

If you want to freeze a given distribution (instead to learn it), use special learner plLearnFrozenDistribution.

plFloat plHMM::train_unsupervised_viterbi ( unsigned int  nstates,
const std::vector< ObservationSequence_t > &  observation_sequences,
int  obs_min_value,
int  obs_max_value,
bool  tabulate_emission_distribution = false,
bool  tabulate_transition_distribution = true,
bool  left_to_right_init = false 
)

Unsupervised training using iterative viterbi algorithm.

Parameters
[in]nstatesthe number of states.
[in]observation_sequencesa vector of observation sequences.
[in]obs_min_valuethe min value for the observation.
[in]obs_max_valuethe max value for the observation.
[in]tabulate_emission_distributiona parameter to say if the emission (observation) distribution should be tabulated or not.
[in]tabulate_transition_distributiona parameter to say if the transition distribution should be tabulated or not.
[in]left_to_right_initif true, state initialization will be "left to right" instead of random

Using this method, the observation is supposed to be one-dimensional integer in the range [obs_min_value,...,obs_max_value]. All distributions are learnt as plLearnLaplace (ie, histograms with one sample point initialization).

plFloat plHMM::update_states_probabilities ( const Observation_t &  observation)

Updates the distribution on the state using a given observation and returns the corresponding log-likelihood.

Parameters
[in]observationthe observation vector.
Returns
the log-likelihood of the observation.

This method allows to use the HMM as a Bayesian filter to update, after each observation, the probability distribution over the states.
